text: - Hello everyone.
My name is Sri Elaprolu.

I'm the Director for
AWS's Generative AI Innovation Center,

and I'm excited today to have
one of our customers here,
FINCA,

and Scott Graham, who's
their VP of Data Science
and Research here with us today.
Scott.
- So FINCA is founded on the belief

that poor people have the
talent and the motivation
to get out of poverty if they had access

to the same resources
that we take for granted.

And so in that vein,
we started by providing

very small loans to women
so that they can invest

in enterprises to feed and
educate their children.

And that now, we're also
expanding into making investments

in an emerging range of
socially motivated companies

that are finding new ways
of meeting the basic needs

of the poor, building on the
success of financial inclusion.
- Awesome, that sounds really impactful.
Tell me a little bit about how you're

leveraging generative AI
and how did you arrive

at that decision,
especially for generative AI
in the research space.
- Well, we are still at a very early stage
in our gen AI journey.
We've just completed a proof of concept
for an Automated Research Assistant.

And the idea is that we
want gen AI to accelerate
the path to knowledge

and enable us as researchers
to map new domains

quickly so that we can support
a very innovative program.

And so for us, gen AI is a
way of helping us to find

information that's out
there in the public domain

that's relevant to the
areas that we're interested

and quickly summarizing it
and generating real insights

into the ways that people
can get out of poverty.
- Awesome.

Can you tell us a little
bit about the impact
the solution has already had?
- Well, I think that the...
So again, this is in a very early stage,

but from the proof of
concept, what we've learned
is that gen AI can be a very powerful way

of quickly mapping out an
initial thesis of impact.
And so we're using a foundation model
to help us take kind of general queries,
general topics around poverty alleviation,

and really flesh those
out into a much more
detailed thesis around how a certain
kind of impact might unfold.

And then we can use
that map that's created

by the foundation model to
then generate new evidence

by going out and feeding
that map into search engines

and research databases
that can then retrieve

all of the information
that's relevant to the topics
that the foundation model generated.
- That's awesome.
How are you leveraging AWS services
like Amazon Bedrock or Amazon Titan?
- Well, so we are all within...
Our entire system is within AWS

and so of course, we
always give priority to

solutions that are native
to the AWS environment

for all the reasons that I'm
sure you guys already know.

But, you know, Bedrock was
very well-suited to our needs

to be able to make an initial
mapping of an impact thesis.

And so just its general
training is well-suited

to creating kind of basic
outline of topics and subtopics.

And, you know, the Titan text
embeddings is very important
for us to be able to extract content
from the documents that we find

and then organize that content
into a document library

that's then accessible
to us as researchers.

- That's good to hear that
you're leveraging Amazon Bedrock
and Titan model.

Curious, can you go a little
bit deeper into explaining
how the solution actually works?
- Sure.
So our Automated Research Assistant
works in three phases,

and in the first phase,
the researcher starts
with a general query around a topic
that we might be interested in,

such as the delivery of
learning through mobile apps.
And so we want to understand that.
So we start with that general query.

And instead of, as we
would've done in the past,

going straight into
search engines, databases,

and manually posing that
query again and again,

we pose that query to a foundation
model, so Amazon Bedrock,
and then Bedrock takes that initial query

and maps out an
understanding of that issue
through what we call a topic model,

which is really just an
outline of themes and subtopics

that respond to its
understanding of that issue.
And then comes process automation.

And so each one of those
subtopics and themes

are then automatically fed
into our search engines,
which are fired up using Apache Airflow.

And so we go from having one
query to having, you know,

a couple dozen now
simultaneous searches happening
through all of these different databases.

And this is all happening
in an automated way.

And so instead of us
manually doing searches,

you know, we have the search
engines fired up automatically.

Then the second phase
is when AuRA has built

a document library using all
of the sources that it found.
And so we now have an outline of the issue

and a whole document
library that's indexed
to each piece of that outline.
So that's the second phase.
Then the third phase is curation.
And this is the really important part

because we don't wanna just
mindlessly depend on the AI.

The whole point of AuRA
is to create an interface

where the human being and
the subject matter expert

can really guide the AI
towards a better representation
of a topic using their knowledge.

And so it's important
in this curation phase,
we've enabled the researcher, for example,
to actually interact with the topic model
to tell it what it thinks is,

to tell the topic model
what we think is good

or less convincing about
its version of the world.

And then you can also
curate the document library.

You can uprate, you
can downrate documents,
you can add new ones, you can delete ones.
And this is important because it allows us

to establish a context of a
source of truth that we trust.

So instead of, you know,
just relying on the black box

of the foundation model,
we're able to build a context
that we actually know and trust.
And then once that curation has happened,
then there's a regeneration

of the topic model using
retrieval augmented generation.
And now we come up with the new version
of that impact pathway,

but instead of it being
whatever the foundation model
thought at the beginning,
it's a version of the impact pathway
that is completely rooted in the context
of our trusted sources of information.

So it's those three stages
of amplifying a query,

building a document library,
and then curating the results

and driving them towards
a better representation
of the issue.
- Which foundation model are you using?
- We're using Anthropic Claude.
- As you were going through this process

of designing a solution and
getting it into production,
what are some lessons that you've learned

that perhaps will be
helpful for other nonprofits
that are looking at gen AI?
- Well, I think for us, you know,

nonprofits do not typically
jump into technology solutions.

We have a real attachment
to our legacy processes,
both in our programs and in our research.
And so I think there is a certain culture

and mind shift that needs
to happen within our space
to be more embracing of technology
as a way of accelerating our impact.
And I think that that's kind of a...
That's, again, something where people

need to become familiar and
they need guidance, you know,

and I think that's where
AWS has been so influential
in FINCA's journey
because they really met us where we were.

You know, very early, we
were just making those

initial migrations to
the cloud, for example,
and AWS really triggered that migration.

And as basic as that was, it
was that crucial first step
that brought us into the realm
of cloud computing, managed services,

and all the things that
go along with that.

So I think that just taking
that first step onto the cloud
is a really important,
you know, that's the foundation,
and having a partner like AWS

that can really help
you navigate that space.

And that really takes the
time to understand who you are

and what you're trying to
achieve so that you can really,
you know, pursue the best path for you.

And I think having that
kind of partnership

really gives you the
confidence to think big

and to even achieve
things that you, you know,

wouldn't have thought
possible before you started.
- Yeah, now that you've gone
through that journey, what's next?
How are you thinking about taking gen AI

into more places that
FINCA is involved in?

- I think for us it's a really
about unlocking the value

of knowledge and the way
that knowledge gets applied
in our field.

Our initial use case
for our proof of concept
is really built around researchers

and helping us kind of
create that foundation
of understanding of a new topic.

We really want that knowledge
to filter into decision making
and into practice.

And so how do we then push
the reporting, for example,

so that we can get more
insights from the documents

that we assemble, what kind of
prompt engineering frameworks
are gonna allow us to really understand,

not just, you know, what is
the structure of an issue,
but like what are the real causal elements
that enable people to get out of poverty?

And so I think that, you
know, this is an area

where we need to learn how to
push the AI itself further.

And we need to also really
work with the implementers

of the programs so that we
can create the kind of outputs

and knowledge products that
will be really practical

and useful to them, not
just to us as researchers
where learning is its own good for us,

but really putting it
in the practical realm
where those learnings can give guidance
to the people making program decisions.
- Thank you, Scott.

Again, appreciate you spending
some time with us today.
And as you continue your journey with AI

and generative AI, let
us know how we can help
and we will take this journey together.
- Thank you.
